ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned a lot about ASL as a language as well as deaf culture
I learned a lot of basic vocab!
I gained a good base of ASL vocabulary, knowledge of ASL's structure and grammar, and better appreciation for and knowledge of Deaf culture.

I feel that I improved in ASL at a greater level than I started the semester believing that I would. We learned many signs in each class and had ample review as well. I learned more than the language of ASL, but also about Deaf Culture and community.

I learned a lot about Deaf culture and history, as well as the norms of Deaf community. I wasn't aware of how uninformed I was about ASL and Deaf culture, and I now feel somewhat more confident to respectfully engage with the Deaf community.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Hard to find vocab and follow during class sometimes.
I liked that the classes were fully immersive and on the shorter side so we could stay focused the whole time
This course sometimes lacks instruction on assignments and feedback for how to improve can be unclear.
The Canvas page was set up well for personal review of signs.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes I liked the course even though it had its challenges.
Yes, not only is it a lighter workload but its really interesting and a fun language to learn
This class requires a lot of additional work outside the classroom. It should only be taken by students who really want to learn ASL.
Absolutely!  ASL is a really interesting language to learn, and while you learn it you gain great insight into Deaf culture. Professor Rubin is fantastic, and you learn a lot by the end.
Yes. The ASL program at Yale is still being built, so it can be a little rocky at times, but you will learn a lot more than you realize.

Yes, I would. I think learning about ASL as a distinct language and Deaf culture is definitely worthwhile. Sure, Prof. Rubin's a bit more particular about student participation than some of the other ASL lectors, but all within reason. As long as you do your assigned work and actively engage/ pay attention in class, it'll all be smooth sailing!
